TaxonomicNotes.value: Two well-differentiated clades (a northern one and a southern one) were formerly recognised, however, more recent data challenges the distinct nature of these two clades (J. Speybroeck pers. comm. 2022).
Lanza et al. (2001) described Speleomantes imperialis sarrabusensis, but it was elevated to full species status by Carranza et al. (2007).
This species was previously included within Pelodytes punctatus. Further systematic studies are required to more clearly determine the distribution of P. ibericus.

This species was formerly regarded as being endemic to the island of Karpathos (Greece); However, recent evidence based on complete mitogenome sequencing showed that individuals from Karpathos and Rhodos form a well-supported monophyletic group with very low genetic distance between them, thus placing the Rhodos population to P. cerigensis and not to P. bedriagae (Toli et al. 2023). The species should be considered endemic to the islands of Karpathos and Rhodos.

Although neither Speybroeck et al. (2020) nor Frost (2024) consider the Karpathos Frog as a separate species (considered a synonym of Pelophylax ridibundus (Pallas, 1771)), recent phylogenetic analysis based on complete mitogenome sequences support the taxonomic distinctiveness of P. cerigensis (Toli et al. 2023). The taxonomy of Pelophylax is complex and further studies are ongoing.
The species status of Pelophylax cretensis is "confirmed" by short mtDNA sequences and a large number of private allozyme alleles not found in any other water frog (P. Beerli pers. comm.).
This species does not produce hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).
This species was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Rana graeca.

Although Schneider and Haxhiu (1994) had difficulty distinguishing the voice of Pelophylax shqipericus from that of P. lessonae, morphology, allozymes, mtDNA sequences, and crossing experiments all indicate that P. shqipericus is distinct from P. lessonae. The species belongs to “lessonae” group and it is sister species to P. lessonae - based on mtDNA and ND3 sequences, 1378 b.p. (Plötner et al. 2012).

This species does not make hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).
Mattoccia et al. (2005) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) separated Salamandrina perspicillata from S. terdigitata.

This species was separated from Lyciasalamandra luschani by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).

The three main recognised phyloclades are highly differentiated from each other, despite relatively small geographical distances among them (Veith et al. 2020). The Kasos Island subpopulation is genetically differentiated from those on the other two islands (Eleftherakos et al. 2007).
Lanza et al. (2001) described this taxon as a subspecies of Speleomantes imperialis, but it was elevated to species status by Carranza et al. (2007).
taxonomicAuthority: Lanza, Leo, Forti, Cimmaruta, Caputo & Nascetti, 2001

TaxonomicNotes.value:
This species had previously been confused with Pelophylax bedriagae (Plötner et al. 2012).

The taxonomic identity of the species is not accepted by the Taxonomic Committee of the Societas Europaea Herpetologica (Speybroeck et al. 2020):
"Using allozymes and mtDNA, a detailed analysis of gene flow patterns across the contact zone of the northern Anatolian lineage and the Balkan lineage of the Pelophylax ridibundus–bedriagae complex in northern Greece revealed the existence of a wide hybrid zone, with introgression detectable over more than 200 km (Hotz et al. 2013). This suggests that the European and Anatolian lineages are conspecific (contra SBC 2010). Since the European lineage splits from a node basal to the diversification of Anatolian lineages with respect to mtDNA according to Plötner et al. (2012), it further suggests that most lineages of this complex are conspecific, with the possible exception of the populations from Syria and Jordan (possibly the ‘true’ bedriagae, see Plötner et al. 2012). On the other hand, Plötner et al. (2010) suggested hybrid breakdown between some of these lineages, indicating incipient speciation.

While undoubtedly the last word on this subject has not been written, the TC felt that it was premature to suggest taxonomic changes, especially as a large taxonomic paper based on genomic variation patterns is in preparation (G. Mazepa pers. comm.). The same applies to the newly proposed P. cypriensis, which was found to be placed between the European and the Anatolian lineages in mtDNA, but grouped with P. cretensis (albeit with very low support) in nuclear DNA (Plötner et al. 2012). For the moment, we thus suggest no change to the taxonomy adopted in SBC2010 for European Pelophylax."
taxonomicAuthority: Plötner, Baier, Akın, Mazepa, Schreiber, Beerli, Litvinchuk, Bilgin, Borkin & Uzzell, 2012

TaxonomicNotes.value: This taxon was removed from the synonymy of Lissotriton boscai by Sequiera et al. (2020) and Speybroeck et al. (2020).
